headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: John Kirby Gives Briefing On Chinese Warship Harassing U.S. Naval Destroyer & War In Ukraine; NTSB At Virginia Site Of Small Plane Crash; FDA To Allow Cancer Drug Imports From China; Apple Unveils Mixed Virtual, Augmented Reality Headset. Aired 2:30-3p ET

utterances.speaker: JOHN KIRBY, NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL COORDINATOR FOR STRATEGIC COMMUNICATIONS
utterances.sentences: I can tell you the Ukrainians have spoken to some of these, quote, unquote, "raids," and have denied participation in them. I will let them speak to that.What I can say, Kelly, and we've said this before, we don't encourage, we don't enable, and we don't support strikes or attacks inside Russia. Our effort -- and we've been competingly plain about this with Ukraine. Our effort is to support them in their self-defense, in defending their territory, their sovereignty. That's what's been violated by Mr. Putin and Russia. That's what we're helping them get back, their independence, their territorial integrity. And that's where the focus is. And I'm not telling you anything that we haven't said pride privately to the Ukrainians in terms of expressing our concerns about that. They know our concerns. They have provided us, all the way up to President Zelenskyy, assurances they will respect those concerns.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Right now, federal investigators are probing the crash of a private plane in rural Virginia that killed four people. The plane was a Cessna Citation.Just before Sunday's crash, F-16 fighter jets intercepted the Cessna over Washington, D.C., airspace. It was headed from Tennessee to Long Island, New York, but instead of landing, it actually turned around and started flying south, entering D.C.'s restricted air space, and it crashed soon afterward. The plane's erratic path had authorities putting the Capitol Complex on elevated alert. Fighter jets were scrambled. They were authorized to hit supersonic speeds, causing a massive sonic boom heard over the region. Officials said they tried to make contact but the pilot of the Cessna was unresponsive. Listen. (BEGIN AUDIO FEED)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: November 611, Victor Golf, Washington Center is looking for you, 133.Niner7.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: If you hear this transmission, contact us.(END AUDIO FEED)

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Let's take you live to the crash site in Vesuvius, Virginia, with CNN's Brian Todd.Brian, what have investigators discovered close to where you are right now?

utterances.speaker: BRIAN TODD, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Boris, we just got an update from the sheriff that said FAA and NTSB investigators are now at the site of the crash. It's several miles into the terrain behind us.This is very steep terrain, very drastic terrain, extremely different to get to a crash site. It takes several hours to get in and back out. We may not get an update for several hours or possibly even until tomorrow after the FAA and NTSB investigators get back from the site. What we have been told is that, from first responders, when they got to the site last night -- and again it took hours and several of them almost got injured getting there. That's how difficult the trek is. When they got there, they spotted what was four or five recognizable pieces of a plane, but one of these told me, quote, "It was no bigger than your arm." There were also human remains at the site, they said. They said the plane left a sizable crater in the ground. From what they saw, that crater, the contours and everything else there, they believe the plane impacted the mountains at a very steep angle, Boris. A very dramatic and horrible scene deep into the mountains where NTSB investigators are liking at that site now. One thing they were looking for is to see whether the plane had any black box, cockpit voice recorder or flight recorder. We are told this particular private jet was not required to have black boxes, so it may not have anything in there. But some of these planes are outfitted with the boxes nonetheless and they'll look to see if they can pull some of those out if they're there -- Boris?

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: It could be a significant piece of evidence in this investigation.Brian Todd, from Vesuvius, Virginia, thank you. I want to turn to CNN transportation analyst, Mary Schiavo. Mary, thank you for being with us. Historically, when you see accidents similar to this one, where a pilot is unresponsive, flying a long distance away from where it's supposed to be, what are some of the causes you have seen create this kind of scenario?

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Mary, you mentioned jets that were scrambled in response to this plane. I'm wondering what the protocol is when a vessel like that enters restricted airspace.

utterances.speaker: SCHIAVO
utterances.sentences: Exactly what happened here. The protocol when an aircraft, any aircraft, an incapacitated pilot situation or just a pilot who is confused, on the wrong path, or someone intending ill intent, that's what the United States and other countries have been trained to do.They try to make contact with the pilot. But also, they can get close enough to literally look in and see, what's the condition of the pilots? Are they slumped over? Are the windows fogged over with ice, et cetera? In other cases, they can see into the cabin windows to see the condition of the passengers on board. The scrambled fighter jets play an important role, sometimes, in the case of sleeping pilots. There were two flights last year, commercial aviation flights, where both pilots fell asleep. One was an Ethiopian airline; one was over Italy. In Italy, there were met with fighter jets and they woke them up. So it's an important role for these fighter jets. And in this case, they did exactly what they were supposed to do.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Sadly with a tragic ending. No survivors on this flight. We look forward to getting more information from investigators soon.Mary Schiavo, we hope you'll come back and help us walk through the evidence.

utterances.speaker: JIM SCIUTTO, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: The FDA is now working with a Chinese drug maker to import a much-needed cancer drug amid what is being called a critical shortage. The chemotherapy medication is one of several in short supply in the U.S. right now.CNN medical correspondent, Meg Tirrell, joins us now. Meg, tell us about this particular drug, what it's used for, and why it's in such short supply.

utterances.speaker: MEG TIRRELL, CNN MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, you know, it's baffling. We hear the stories over and over again with cancer drugs and other medicines.This is called Cisplatin, and it's incredibly important for chemotherapy regiments for a number of cancers, from lung cancer to bladder cancer, cervical cancer, ovarian cancer and testicular cancer, where it can be curative for many patients. The National Cancer Institute estimates it's used in between 10 percent to 20 percent of all cancer patients. So the fact this was in shortage since February, it has caused a ton of problems for doctors and patients. They've to delay treatments, substitute other medicines and, in some cases, ration care for the people most likely to be cured. So it's a terrible situation. The FDA is now saying it will allow the temporary importation of a version of this drug from a Chinese drug maker. The FDA commissioner tweeting on late Friday night, quote, "The agency recognizes the importance of a stable, safe supply of critical drugs used in oncology, especially those in potentially curative or life- extending situations." They say they have taken steps for temporary application of certain approved versions of Cisplatin products from FDA-registered facilities. So, Jim, the ordering of this should start tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Any reason to have concerns about the quality of drugs? Or are there international standards, so people can be comfortable?

utterances.speaker: TIRRELL
utterances.sentences: There are standards. The FDA says it can assure the safety. This plant has other FDA-approved medicines. This one just is not approved in the U.S.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Apple unveils its first major product in nearly 10 years. So was it worth the wait? CNN's Jon Sarlin is there at the Apple campus for the big reveal.What do you think? What are they showing off here? JON SARLIN, CNN DIGITAL PRODUCER & CNN BUSINESS HOST, "NIGHTCAP": Brianna, this is Apple's biggest product probably since the iPad. Vision Pro, Apple's new augmented reality headset, AR. So virtual reality, a screen in front of you. This is augmented reality. Apple says that this blends the real world and the virtual world. They're banking that you're going to shell a lot of money for an Apple computer that you'll be placing on top of your head. It's got two hours of battery life, 4K video, and they teased how it will be used. And they suggested you can use it for work, showing how someone can have multiple screens up in front of them. They show a home cinema of a TV of any size. And also a collaboration with Disney. Bob Iger came on stage and showed how Baby Yoda might one day soon appear on Apple's Vision Pro.

utterances.speaker: SARLIN
utterances.sentences: That's the big question, right? Because, you know, it's been predicted for a long time that there might be this future with VR, with AR.But the problem is people haven't wanted to put these computers on top of their heads. You might remember Google Glass was going to be the future of computers in 2013. Well, it was a huge failure, one of the big tech failures of the last decade. But Apple is banking that the technology has developed and that their design team has created a product that consumers will want to spend a lot of money. The price has not been announced yet but it's rumored to be in the thousands of dollars.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: All right. I still want to see Baby Yoda, Jon, I'll tell you that.Thank you so much. I think we'll see more of this to come. We do appreciate the update. Boris?
